title: 114_hr2332
content: The Act titled "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a Transformational Infrastructure Competitive Grant Program. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a transformational infrastructure competitive grant program under the Secretary of Transportation. Grants can be awarded to state governments, local governments, transit agencies, and port authorities for eligible projects that significantly impact metropolitan areas, regions, or the United States, including highway and bridge projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects in the United States, including highway, bridge, public transportation, and rail projects. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects in the United States, including rail, port, aviation, water, and coordination with environmental agencies for water infrastructure projects. Eligibility for grants requires applications meeting specific criteria. The "Nation Building Here at Home Act of 2015" establishes a competitive grant program for infrastructure projects in the United States. Eligible entities must submit applications meeting specified criteria determined by the Secretary of Engineers. Criteria for grant awards will be issued within 90 days of the Act's enactment, including considerations for financial commitments. The Secretary will establish criteria for grant consideration, including financial commitments from non-Federal sources. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 100 percent. Grants will be distributed equitably, address urban and rural needs, and promote veteran training and employment. The grants for projects must address urban and rural needs, promote veteran training and employment, and ensure a percentage is spent through small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Projects must comply with Title 40 requirements and adhere to Buy America provisions. Buy America provision in the Act requires all iron, steel, and manufactured goods for a project to be produced in the United States, with exceptions for cases where it's not in the public interest, not available in sufficient quantities, or increases project costs by over 25 percent. The Buy America provision in the Act mandates that goods for a project must be produced in the United States, with exceptions for cases where it's not in the public interest, not available in sufficient quantities, or increases project costs by over 25 percent. The Secretary must provide detailed justification for any waiver granted. The provision must align with U.S. obligations under international agreements. The Secretary must ensure grants are used efficiently and make information public. The Secretary must ensure grants are used efficiently, make information public, and coordinate with relevant agencies for environmental reviews to expedite project delivery. Authorization of appropriations is provided for grant funding. Authorization of appropriations totaling $985 billion is authorized for the Secretary to make grants under the program for fiscal years 2016 through 2020. The funds will be allocated for various project uses as outlined in subsection (c)(1). Authorization of appropriations totaling $985 billion for grants under the program for fiscal years 2016 through 2020. Funds allocated for projects in subsection (c)(1) include 4 percent for projects in subparagraph (E) and 9 percent for projects in subparagraph (F). The Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative is authorized with $985 billion for grants from 2016 to 2020, with specific allocations for different types of projects. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation, will establish a Nation Building Here at Home Financing Initiative within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary may issue bonds up to $300 billion with specific terms and conditions. Proceeds from the bonds will be made available to the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Transportation may use the proceeds from bonds issued under subsection (b) to carry out the program established under section 2(a) of this Act. The Secretary of Transportation must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment, detailing the transportation needs of the United States for the next 20, 30, and 50 years.
